content:
The Bug Catcher

Clean up your logic from Lesson 2 by adding functions to make your code easier to re-use. You will learn how to use IF statements to help your program make smart decisions, display messages to your players with print statements, and use variables to increase or decrease values like scores or health. We will also cover how to swap images to change how characters look, keep track of clicks using counters, and add exciting new assets to build your very own interactive story.

ðŸ“Œ Lesson Objectives

  • Functions: Re-usable custom blocks
  • More practice with the Location Block
  • Import backgrounds from the Background Library
  • Learn how to show / hide a sprite
  • Multiple Event Listener blocks
  • Continue using the Print block for Testing
  • Keep track of a variable's count
  • More practice with IF Blocks

ðŸš€ Tutorial

We're going to speed up the text description since most of this has been covered.

  1. Let's start this off by creating a New Sprite Lab project named:

L3 - The Bug Catcher

Import Backgrounds

  1. Now, above the the Stage/Canvas find and click the Backgrounds button/tab.

  2. Click on the New Background + button.

  3. In the pop-up search Village. Five images should appear. Select each one. then click Done.

  4. Click the Code button to go back to your Stage/Canvas

Import Costumes

  1. Set the first scene by snapping a Blocks > World > set to background block under the when run block.

  2. Change the background to one of the Village backgrounds with imported.

  3. Click on the Costumes button above the Stage/Canvas and select: New Costume + and search for Pig. Find and select the Pig with Axe.

  4. Again, Click on the Costumes button and select: New Costume + and search for bugs. Add 5 bugs, click Done, then click back on the Code button to back to your Stage/Canvas.

  5. Once more let's a new costume. Type: Start and select the black start button. Click Done and then click the Code button to go back to the Canvas/Stage

Set the stage

  1. Let's add two sprites.

  2. First, add the Start button place it in around the center of the canvas.

  3. Second, add the Pig with Axe sprite down towards the bottom of the dirt path.

On-Click Hide Sprite - Event Block

  1. Add a new when [sprite] clicked event block. Change it to the Start button block.

  2. Then snap a Blocks > Sprites > remove [sprite] block under the when [sprite] clicked event block and change it to the Start button block.

Functions

functions are basically containers that run a set of action or blocks and can be re-used over and over.

  1. To get a feel for functions let's create one for backgrounds using IF Blocks like we did lesson 2.

  2. Grab the block: Blocks > Variables > set [counter] to and snap it under the pig sprite

  3. Then snap a Blocks > Math > [0] block to the set [counter] to block.

  4. Add a print block with double quotes and the counter variable so it says the following on the Stage/Canvas. [print]["counter"][counter]

counter = 0

  1. Now click on the Blocks > Functions > Create a Function and name it scene_1

  2. Inside this new block add a Blocks > Logic > if [counter] = [ ] block inside this function.

  3. Snap a Blocks > Math > [0] block after the equal sign in the empty space.

  4. Inside the if block add a set background to block and change the image to the first village background.

  5. Then click the Close button to back to the workspace.

  6. Drag and snap the Blocks > Functions > scene_1 block under the remove sprite block.

  7. Duplicate the print line blocks and add it under scene_1 block. Click the Run button and press the Start block. This should set the counter value to 0 and change the background.

  1. Let's continue practicing with functions by first clicking on the edit button on the function scene_1 in the Workspace.

  2. Now add a Lady bug sprite under the background and also include a set [Lady Bug] size to [50] under the sprite block. This block is found in Blocks > Sprites

  3. Now position the Lady bug sprite. You won't be able to see it but put it on the fence towards the bottom-left. - Click the Close button to go back to the Workspace.

  4. From the Blocks > Events add a When [sprite] clicked block to the Workspace and change the sprite to the Lady Bug.

  5. From the Blocks > Sprites snap under the event block the remove [sprite] block and set it to the Lady Bug.

Test it out by clicking the Run button.
Then click the Start
Then click the Lady Bug. It should disappear.

  1. From the Blocks > Variables snap a change counter by block under the remove [Lady Bug] block and then from the Blocks > Math toolbar add a [0] block to it and chang the number to 1.

  2. Below this block add a copy of the [print]["counter = "][counter] blocks. This will display the updated value on the Stage/Canvas

  3. Let's create a new Function called: scene_2

  4. In the scene_2 function add an if counter = [ ] block. Then from the Blocks > Math put the [0] block in the empty space and change the number to [1].

  5. Now inside the if block add a set background to block and change the background to the second village image. Click the Close button and test it out.

  1. Repeat the process for each bug you add. Take a look at the videos below.
  1. This ends the lesson.

ðŸ§© Challenge

Move the Piggy

Video: 09 - Challenge Complete

  1. At the top of the Lesson 2 Sprite Lab project click the Remix button and rename it L3C1 - Move the Piggy
  2. Now that all the functions exist, your next task is to make the pig sprite move to different locations on the ground for each new background change.

Hint: to move the pig sprite try using the [sprite] jump to [random location] but replace the random location with actual coordiates.

Video: 10 location x,y block

Remove Print Blocks

Video: 11 Piggy Hints

  1. Once you complete challenge 1: Move the Piggy.
  2. Remove all the: print blocks so that the number value for the counter doesn't display on the stage.
  3. Now for each scene have the pig save something like: "Can you find the Lady Bug"... do this for every bug.
  4. Finally, add an event block for the last bug when you click it. Have the pig say... "Yay, you caught all the bugs!"
